nodes.text: When a person is induced to state publicly something contrary to his private opinion, his private opinion will shift to agree with the public statement, and this opinion change will be larger when the external inducement (reward) is minimal and smaller when the reward is larger

Laboratory experiment manipulated reward magnitude (control, one dollar, twenty dollars) while inducing subjects to tell a waiting person that a boring task was enjoyable to create forced compliance and measure subsequent opinion change

Cognitive dissonance theory: dissonance arises from inconsistency between private belief and public statement, dissonance magnitude is inversely related to strength of external justification (reward), and dissonance is reduced by changing private opinion
Prediction derived: larger reward will produce smaller subsequent opinion change because greater reward provides stronger consonant justification reducing dissonance

Sample and procedure: 71 male introductory psychology students recruited via course requirement; tasks made deliberately boring; cover story and staged interactions used; final interview by blind interviewer with four rating questions

Experimental conditions: Control (no request to lie), One Dollar (paid $1 to tell waiting student tasks were fun), Twenty Dollars (paid $20 to tell waiting student tasks were fun); conversation recorded and later rated
Data exclusions: 11 of 71 subjects excluded for suspicion, admitting to being hired, refusing payment, or other protocol breaks, leaving 20 subjects per condition for analysis
Primary result on enjoyment ratings: One Dollar subjects rated the tasks significantly more enjoyable (mean +1.35) than Control (mean -0.45), difference significant at p < .02

Result on reward magnitude: Twenty Dollar subjects rated tasks near Control (mean -0.05) and significantly lower than One Dollar subjects; difference between One Dollar and Twenty Dollar significant (p approx .03), supporting inverse relation prediction
Secondary measures: ratings of how much subjects learned showed negligible differences across conditions, indicating effect specificity to the dissonance-relevant attitude

Secondary outcomes: desire to participate again and perceived scientific importance tended to follow the same direction as enjoyment (One Dollar > Control; Twenty Dollar intermediate) but were weaker and less statistically robust

Alternative explanation tested: greater self-persuasion due to more persuasive or longer performance by One Dollar subjects was evaluated by blind ratings of taped conversations on content, persuasiveness, and time spent

Ratings evidence: two independent raters (reliabilities .61 to .88) found Twenty Dollar subjects slightly higher on content and persuasiveness, and only time spent approached significance, so One Dollar subjects did not improvise more convincingly

Authors' inference: the observed greater attitude change in the low-reward condition cannot be explained by greater rehearsal or persuasive performance, supporting cognitive dissonance reduction as mechanism

Conclusion: Experimental results strongly corroborate cognitive dissonance predictions that forced compliance changes private opinion and that smaller external justification yields greater internal attitude change
